Hi,

The feature for 4.5 looks like it would cover the situations I can  
imagine at the moment, as long as the data point can be an array of  
arrays to match a method parameter list.

Thanks David

On Oct 21, 2007, at 1:40 PM, David Saff wrote:

> Kendall,
>
> You can use the default parameter supplier, and supply each fish name
> as a constant:
>
> @DataPoint public static String ALBACORE = "albacore";
> @DataPoint public static String ZINGLE = "zingle";
>
> This gets tedious, so in 4.5 (I'll try to get a snapshot out soon),  
> you can say:
>
> @DataPoints public static String[] FISH = {"albacore",  
> "alewife", ... }
>
> or
>
> @DataPoints public static String[] FISH = readFishFromDb();
>
> Does that help?
>
> David Saff
>
> On 10/21/07, Kendall Shaw <queshaw@...> wrote:
> > Hi,
> >
> > I can see the distinction you are making. I would be stating a  
> universal
> > truth, and supplying representative parameters.
> >
> > The 200 strings I was referring to was a comparison to the  
> example using
> > @Before(first=-100, last=100).
> >
> > In the example, a largish number of parameters can be supplied  
> because
> > you can describe the integers as a range. If your theory was
> > parameterized by fish names, you couldn't supply a range of fish  
> names
> > using something like: @Fish(first=new "albacore", last="zingle"),  
> right?
> > I wouldn't want to put 200 or so strings with fish names in them  
> in the
> > annotation.
> >
> > Abusing Paramaterized to state a universal true, I can supply  
> parameters
> > to my imitation theory by putting Objects in an array. I would  
> rather
> > use Theory for my theory, I suppose.
> >
> > How would you supply representative parameters to a Theory that  
> are 200
> > file names, or 1000 different DOM nodes etc.?
> >
> > Kendall
> >
> > On Sun, 2007-10-21 at 13:50 -0400, David Saff wrote:
> > > Kendall,
> > >
> > > The Parameters runner and Theories runner are built to handle
> > > different scenarios. With a Theory, you're building a Universal
> > > Truth; you're stating "this holds for any possible parameters  
> (that
> > > meet my assumptions). Here are some example parameters." With a
> > > Parameters method, you're building an Answer Key; you're saying  
> "this
> > > holds for these values exactly, and possibly others, but I make no
> > > promises." Are you building an Answer Key, or stating a Universal
> > > Truth?
> > >
> > > That said, from a practical point of view, the ease of using each
> > > runner depends on how you want to specify your data--I hope  
> that this
> > > limitation will lessen in future releases. Where are your 200  
> strings
> > > coming from? Thanks,
> > >
> > > David Saff
> > >
> > > On 10/20/07, Kendall Shaw <queshaw@...> wrote:
> > > > The popper tutorial that the junit 4.4 release notes refers  
> to shows
> > > > an example of a parameter supplier, which allows data points for
> > > > theories to come from parameters of an annotation:
> > > >
> > > > http://popper.tigris.org/tutorial.html
> > > >
> > > > The example allows you to use the parameters of an annotation as
> > > > parameters for the theory:
> > > >
> > > > @Theory public void  
> multiplyIsInverseOfDivideWithInlineDataPoints(
> > > > @Between(first=-100, last=100) int amount,
> > > > @Between(first=-100, last=100) int m
> > > > ) {
> > > > assumeThat(m, not(0));
> > > > assertThat(new Dollar(amount).times(m).divideBy(m).getAmount(),
> > > > is(amount));
> > > > }
> > > >
> > > > I think the parameters first and last have to be compile time
> > > > constants, is that right? How can I I test with parameters that
> > > > aren't constants? I wouldn't want to put 200 strings in the
> > > parameter
> > > > list, for example. I could use integers like the Between  
> annotation
> > > > above, as indices into an array or function I guess.
> > > >
> > > > I used the @Parameters JUnit annotation instead for a test. From
> > > what
> > > > I see so far, that looks to me like a simpler solution in  
> general,
> > > > than using @Theory. Is that right?
> > > >
> > > > Kendall
> > > >
> > > >
